channel.title: Hanami Mastery newest episodes!

item.title: #43 Connect your ruby app with google drive.
item.description: In the world of amazing technology pace, integrations between services are the key to success and the same applies to ruby projects. In this episode, we integrate our Hanami application with Google drive.
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Wilgosz

item.title: #42 Best way to work with Front Matter in Ruby!
item.description: If you want to work with front_matter in Ruby, you need to know the front_matter_parser gem. Here is everything you need.
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Wilgosz

item.title: #41 Deploying Hanami Apps to Render
item.description: Learn how to quickly deploy Hanami apps to production-ready server, using Render hosting provider, the best replacement for Heroku right now.
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Wilgosz

item.title: #40 Spin up your Hanami apps easily with Hanamismith
item.description: I always liked rails templating collections that allowed us to quickly compose ruby apps. Now the same is possible for Hanami!
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Wilgosz

item.title: #39 HTML from markdown made simple!
item.description: Have you ever considered how to efficiently render HTML out of your markdown input in ruby? Here we cover this problem with additional custom cosmetic improvements.
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Wilgosz

item.title: #38 Intro to Apps architecture - Level 1: Context
item.description: In this episode we are going to design high-level concept of Hanami-based Web application. In 2023 we're going to automate a few things, and create production-ready Hanami application, that will support our content creation.
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Wilgosz

item.title: #37 Advanced CLI tools with Ruby and dry-cli!
item.description: Utility scripts in Ruby can be very powerful, but also very messy. In this episode I showcase dry-cli, to help you maintain advanced ruby CLI programs.
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Wilgosz

item.title: Hanami Mastery 2022 - Year Summary and next plans.
item.description: The 2022 was a big progress for me in multiple fields, but 2023 is going to be even bigger. Let's summarize the year, stop for a while to thank everyone, and figure out plans for the upcoming year!
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Wilgosz

item.title: #36 Scale your app with slices!
item.description: In Hanami, you can reduce technical debt and keep fast development when the application grows. For that, slices is the key feature to revolutionize the way you think about web applications in Ruby.
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Wilgosz

item.title: #35 Halt or Handle? Dealing with exceptions in Hanami apps!
item.description: Handling exceptions is one of the most needed features for any applications that can scale. If you are wondering, how to handle errors in Hanami 2 applications, don't look for more.
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Wilgosz

item.title: #34 Safe gem upgrades with pessimize gem
item.description: Upgrading gems in the bigger project can become a hustle if you don't use tools like pessimize to help you deal with them safely.
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Wilgosz

item.title: #33 Deep dive into semantic versioning in Ruby
item.description: Semantic versioning is a useful approach to version your projects or gems - and that will be necessary at some point if you seriously think about ruby career.
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Wilgosz

item.title: #32 Pagination in Hanami apps with ROM
item.description: There are plenty of popular ways to handle pagination in Ruby apps. But did you know, that ROM supports Pagination out of the box? And so Hanami does? In this episode, I'll show you how to quickly implement pagination from scratch for your Hanami projects.
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Wilgosz

item.title: #31 ROM-Factory - Your testing buddy for Hanami apps
item.description: If you have experience testing ruby applications, I'm sure you've heard about FactoryBot. Here I show you the alternative, suited for ROM-based applications, including Hanami 2.
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Wilgosz

item.title: #30 ROM - Mapping is everything
item.description: Understand data mapping in ROM, on all levels! In this episode we go through examples of simple to complex data mapping with ROM, with real usecases for each one.
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Wilgosz

item.title: #29 Leverage ROM Repositories
item.description: Relations are the heart of ROM, but for bigger applications, you'll appreciate to know repositories.
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Wilgosz

item.title: #28 Configure ROM from scratch
item.description: Hanami 2.0 comes without the persistence layer nor views preconfigured. It is useful then to know how to set up the best ORM available in the Ruby ecosystem.
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Wilgosz

item.title: #27 Integrate Sidekiq with Hanami Applications
item.description: Sidekiq is probably the most known background processing engine for Ruby projects. In this episode I'll show you how to integrate it in Hanami applications!
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Wilgosz

item.title: #26 Generate Sitemaps for Hanami applications!
item.description: Sitemap is one of the core features for any web application, to make sure your site is indexed properly. Here is how to generate sitemaps in Hanami applications using sitemap_generator gem!
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Wilgosz

item.title: #25 Branch for a next Launch - Simplecov!
item.description: Enchance your test coverage reports by mastering the Simplecov gem!
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Wilgosz

item.title: #24 7 Levels of test coverage
item.description: Do you measure your test coverage? Do you know that everything below 80% is irrelevant? Here I list 7 levels of test coverage, check out where you are!
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Wilgosz

item.title: #23 Rubocop - 4 ways to reduce your frustration!
item.description: Rubocop recently managed to be listed as one of the most loved and most frustrating ruby gems which is quite an achievement. In this episode, I'll show you how to keep it only in the loved section.
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Wilgosz

item.title: #22 Hanami Router with TDD
item.description: Routing is one of the basic components of any web application. In this episode I'll dig a bit into the Hanami router from the usage point of view, covering why it's great and how to work with it.
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Wilgosz

item.title: #21 JSON Serialization with Alba in Hanami
item.description: Serialize your API responses in Hanami applications with alba - the fastest ruby serialization gem
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Wilgosz

item.title: #20 dry-validation - The one gem to validate them all!
item.description: Validating data input is an extremely important problem to tackle in all applications. In Ruby ecosystem there is no better tool for that than dry-validation. Here is why!
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Wilgosz

item.title: #19 The underrated power of dry-schema
item.description: dry-schema is an extremely powerful and validation engine for Ruby applications and as it's a built-in validation solution for Hanami projects, It is important to get familiar with it.
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Wilgosz

item.title: #18 Fun with Hanami Actions
item.description: Hanami actions are one of the richest building blocks in terms of available features and in this episode I want to go over them, showing how to validate params, handle errors and and use before or after hooks.
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Wilgosz

item.title: #17 Inline documentation - the secret habit of successful devs.
item.description: Everyone would love to have a secret power. A skill that makes you a hero. There is no one such skill, but in this episode, I'll talk about inline documentation - a great skill that can make you a better developer.
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Wilgosz

item.title: #16 Your app is not your business!
item.description: Check out these 4 ways to separate your business logic aside of your application layer in Ruby applications.
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Wilgosz

item.title: #15 Dependency Injection in Ruby - GOD Level! Meet dry-system! (Part 2)
item.description: Dependency injection brings you great power, but comes with its own headaches. If you can get rid of them, You're left with the power only. In Ruby, with dry-system, it's possible. Here is how!
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Wilgosz

item.title: #14 Dependency Injection in Ruby from 0 to hero (Part 1)
item.description: Dependency Injection is an extremely useful programming technique and can be easily implemented in Ruby! Mastering it is an important skill to leverage the power of Hanami applications! dry-container is one way to help you with it!
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Wilgosz

item.title: #13 A sneak-peak into dependency loading with Hanami and dry-container
item.description: dry-system and dry-container are extremely powerful tools and if you understand how to work with them, you'll never look back. It's amazing that Hanami uses them by default! Check out some useful debugging tips!
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Wilgosz

item.title: #12 Authorization with JWT in Hanami applications!
item.description: Authorizating your API applications can be trivial, if you have proper tolls to do it. Here I showcase how authorization with JWT can be done effortless in any ruby application by using Hanami 2 as an example.
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Wilgosz

item.title: #11 Effective programming in ruby
item.description: 2 real-world examples of using algebraic effects in Hanami ruby applications with dry-effects.
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Wilgosz

item.title: #10 Model your business with structs on steroids - dry-struct in action!
item.description: A struct with static type check for all attributes is a pretty useful thing in Ruby and all other languages. Here are 3 examples of useful applications for typed structs using dry-struct.
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Wilgosz

item.title: ROM and Sequel over ActiveRecord?
item.description: I've wondered why Hanami uses sequel under the hood. There are some problems with ActiveRecord, but I've wanted to know exactly, what it is about. Here is the summary of my foundings.

item.title: The secret of stunning OSS contributions!
item.description: If you can contribute to open-source, do it only if you can benefit from it. So if you can't benefit, either drop the idea or... make it beneficial!
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Wilgosz

item.title: #9 Integrate Hanami 2.0 with your Database using ROM
item.description: Every application needs persistence. Saving records in a database is just a must. Here is how you can do it in Hanami applications!
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Wilgosz

item.title: Why ALL APIs are inconsistent?
item.description: One of the most common problems in web applications, is to update the application state based on the business rules. How it's possible, that API specification does not cover it?
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Wilgosz

item.title: #8 Learn new things easily - mapping Rails to Hanami!
item.description: When I've started with learning Hanami, I've struggled a lot because of the different concepts Hanami has over Rails. In this episode of Hanami Mastery I'm mapping Rails to Hanami for easier learning.
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Wilgosz

item.title: I've made a dependency graph for all DRY gems of Ruby gems family!
item.description: Have you ever wondered which DRY-RB library learn first? I did when I started with DRY-RB. I hope this will help!
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Wilgosz

item.title: #7 Untangle your code with MORE than service objects! Meet dry-monads!
item.description: Everyone knows how messy Rails controllers can be come. In this episode, I'm implementing the service-pattern on steroids using dry-monads in my sample Rails application.
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Wilgosz

item.title: Why I'm giving so much appreciation everywhere?
item.description: People seem to be surprised being mentioned in my articles, tweets, videos, or when I send a personal 'thank you' email. I've decided to sort it out here...
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Wilgosz

item.title: #6 Complex Ruby Transformations made simple with dry-transformer!
item.description: Have you ever need to stringify keys outside of rails? Whether you want to import or export CSVs or communicate with external services you may need to parse the input to different output. 'dry-transformer' can help you with it.
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Wilgosz

item.title: Hanami architecture explained
item.description: People ask me about the simple explanation of Hanami architecture. Why is it so complicated? Is it? I'll try to explain it in simple words.

item.description: Configuring projects and components is one of the most common features in programming in general. dry-configurable is a standalone gem providing you exactly this in Ruby! Read about how to use it.

item.description: Use constantize, classify, underscore and MORE on Strings in Pure ruby! Use dry-inflector to quickly apply non-standard string transformations!

item.title: My attempt to change the world of Open-Source financing.

item.title: #3 Style your Hanami App with Bulma using Hanami Assets
item.description: In this episode I make use of Bulma CSS framework and integrate it with Hanami 2.0 application to prettify it with the least effort possible.
